channel.title: Conflict – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: Game-Changer: The Rise and Expansion of the Global University
item.dc:creator: Bradley Williams
item.description: There is a de facto 21st century gold rush among elite universities in the United States. In the age of globalized capital, privatization of the state, and commodified education, top-ranked, private universities and colleges are expanding beyond U.S. borders and building proxy campuses in locations fundamental to American economic and military interests. Of the U.S. … Continue reading Game-Changer: The Rise and Expansion of the Global University →

item.title: Bullet Films
item.dc:creator: Joscelyn Jurich
item.description: An uncomfortably intimate close-up of a young man’s face opens one of the most recent “bullet films” by Syrian film collective Abounaddara entitled “Don’t Forget the Plums.” The penetrating eyes of the unnamed speaker confront the viewer as he gives cautionary advice about how to deal with the media: “When you’re live on air, the … Continue reading Bullet Films →

item.title: Book Review: Guban by Abdi Latif Ega
item.dc:creator: Rabah Omer
item.description: The events unfolding around the political arrest of an apolitical businessman tells the story of a politically troubled country. The author of Guban, Abdi Latif Ega, cleverly weaves the social, environmental, cultural and political provisions of Somalia to voice the journey of a largely misunderstood country that came to be viewed as predestined to failure … Continue reading Book Review: Guban by Abdi Latif Ega →

item.title: Never-Ending Story: The American Press Fails on Iran
item.dc:creator: Roxanne Emadi
item.description: The big, bad Iran nuclear threat is one of the American news media’s favorite evergreen stories. Year after year, it picks up where it left off: Enrichment, sanctions, red lines, the usual. In November, the media circus on Iran exploded. From Foreign Affairs’ catastrophe “Time to attack Iran,” to The New York Times Magazine’s seemingly-million-word “Will Israel attack … Continue reading Never-Ending Story: The American Press Fails on Iran →

item.title: Liberation Square
item.dc:creator: Thalia Beaty
item.description: Ashraf Khalil’s Liberation Square offers a gritty and engrossing account of the events that took place in Egypt in 2011, using the voices of both Egypt’s most prominent political observers and the activists who risked everything in pursuit of an ever-elusive dream. Khalil, who has covered regional politics from Cairo, Jerusalem, and Iraq for a variety of … Continue reading Liberation Square →
